text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single full-page diagram with central vertical vine splitting into lateral branches; main text absent except brief captions and leaf labels integrated into the decorative scheme; wide painted margins occupied by roundels connected by narrow scroll-bands; strong visual hierarchy given to the central Caritas roundel, with subsidiary virtues arrayed around

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf background reserved for all virtue personifications, emphasizing their spiritual importance; rich vermilion diaper pattern provides visual unity; blue and green vines create structural framework; white highlights model drapery folds; red and blue robes alternate to guide the eye; pigment layers remain well preserved with minimal darkening of white.

features: Central vertical axis organizing root, trunk and summit
Radial lateral branches for cardinal virtues
Prominent central Caritas roundel as focal point
Overlapping vine tendrils suggesting organic growth
Symmetrical balance of left and right branches

decorative_elements: Green vine scrolls with star-shaped leaves

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid quill-pen drawing with fine and bold strokes delineating figures and vines
drawing_technique.shading_method: Subtle white highlight on robes and flesh, with minimal parallel hatching
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling without true linear perspective, depth implied by overlapping vines and frames

reading_order: Bottom root Humilitas to trunk virtues ascending
Branches radiate from Caritas central node to cardinal virtues

scene_relationships.subject: Humilitas
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Gives rise to Fides as the first trunk virtue
visual_connections: Green trunk vine originates at Humilitas’s staff
Red robe echoes the color in Fides’s drapery
Kneeling gaze directed upward toward Fides

scene_relationships.subject: Fides
visual_connections: Trunk vine emerges from Fides’s lectern
Blue of Fides’s tunic repeated in Caritas’s robe
Leaf labels around each share star-shaped form

scene_relationships.subject: Caritas
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Central node from which Spes and cardinal virtues branch
visual_connections: Six lateral vines spring symmetrically from Caritas
Gold background unites all virtue roundels
Hands holding chalice and paten mirror trunk’s bifurcation

scene_relationships.subject: Spes
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Trunk continues to the summit Sapientia
visual_connections: Vine leads from Caritas to Spes
Green mantle of Spes matches vine color
Upturned gesture echoes Humilitas’s upward gaze

scene_relationships.subject: Sapientia
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Terminal summit of the trunk hierarchy
visual_connections: Trunk culminates at Sapientia’s book
Crown motif picks up gold leaf background
Gesture of book-holding closes the vertical sequence

scene_relationships.subject: Prudentia
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Branch subordinate to Caritas central node
visual_connections: Lateral vine from Caritas connects to Prudentia
Blue robe of Prudentia echoes Fides’s blue
Leaf labels around share consistent green outline

scene_relationships.subject: Iustitia
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Branch subordinate to Caritas central node
visual_connections: Lateral vine from Caritas connects to Iustitia
Balance scale motif contrasts chalice of Caritas
Gold frame décor identical to other virtues

scene_relationships.subject: Temperantia
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Branch subordinate to Caritas central node
visual_connections: Green vine from Caritas attaches to Temperantia
Red and white robe pattern balances Caritas’s colors
Leaf inscriptions echo in shape and color

scene_relationships.subject: Fortitudo
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Branch subordinate to Caritas central node
visual_connections: Lateral vine leads from Caritas to Fortitudo
Sword motif contrasts book motif of Sapientia
Gold leashed frame consistent across all roundels

visual_continuity: Uniform orange diaper pattern behind all scenes
Star-shaped leaf labels around each virtue
Circular gilt frames with punch-dot ornamentation

content_theme.scene_description:
Primary Scene Analysis:
The central Caritas roundel occupies the midpoint of the page, measuring approximately 6 cm in diameter, set against a burnished gold leaf ground within a punched gilt frame. The figure is draped in a red tunic and white mantle, holding a chalice in her right hand and a paten in her left. Her head is inclined, and her feet rest on a tiny green cushion. Surrounding her, six green vine tendrils sprout evenly, each terminating in a star-shaped leaf inscribed with sub-virtues in Gothic textualis miniature. The overall layout is strictly symmetrical, with Caritas as the focal axis from which cardinal virtues and theological virtues radiate.
Secondary Elements:
Marginal roundels in the painted borders depict supporting personifications and exemplar figures, each connected by narrow scroll-bands to the main frame, reinforcing the conceptual extension of the virtues hierarchy. The lateral branches integrate spatially with the vertical trunk, creating a cohesive diagram where secondary virtues orbit the central Caritas node. Scene transitions rely on the vine motif, guiding the eye organically from root to summit and then outward to lateral virtues.
Visual-Textual Relationships:
Each virtue circle is accompanied by inscribed leaf labels that function as visual glosses to the verbal hierarchy. Textual banners in the margins name the marginal figures, linking them to the interior virtues. The interplay of green labels on gold and orange grounds creates strong visual emphasis on the names. The diagrammatic layout suggests a reading order that moves from the root caption at lower margin, upward along the vine, and outward to the cardinal virtues, reinforcing the pedagogical sequence.

technical_features.material: Premium calfskin vellum with smooth, well-pumiced surface; single folio from a quaternion gathering with ruled ink lines
technical_features.preservation_condition: Pigments remain vivid with minimal flaking in red areas; slight cockling at margins; modern stabilization evident on lower margin
notable_physical_characteristics: Visible underdrawing beneath green leaf labels
Raised gesso preparation under gold leaf

functional_analysis.primary_function: Didactic allegorical diagram for moral instruction
functional_analysis.intended_audience: Clerical and monastic readers, particularly those engaged in preaching or moral education

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: Created in a mid-13th-century European workshop, this elegantly executed Tree of Virtues reflects the scholastic impulse to order moral theology visually. The use of a central vertical axis crowned by Sapientia demonstrates an integration of Neoplatonic hierarchical structure with Christian ethics, situating humility at the root and divine wisdom at the summit. The rich vermilion diaper background and lavish gold leaf framing indicate a high-status commission, perhaps intended for an intellectualized monastic audience in a cathedral school. Stylistically, the fluid penwork and layered pigment application reveal a mature gothic hand, closely related to the Parisian School but showing local workshop adaptations in color palette and decorative punchwork. Iconographically, the coupling of Caritas’s chalice motif with branch-borne cardinal virtues underscores the primacy of charity in medieval moral thought. The marginal roundels of exemplary figures extend the diagram’s didactic reach, offering scriptural and patristic precedents for each virtue. Comparatively, this manuscript shares compositional affinities with the Psalter of Blanche of Castile and exhibits innovative spatial integration of text and image not seen in earlier moral trees. By balancing traditional iconography with novel diagrammatic clarity, it bridges the boundary between manuscript illumination and pedagogical charting, reflecting wider 13th-century developments in visual theology.
